I’m using a tag+footer protocol in this chat:

- I’ll start line 1 with `!<tag>` where `<tag>` is one of: `<g> <q> <o> <c> <o_f>`.
- You must mirror my tag on the first line of every reply, like `<q>` or `<o>`.
- You must end every reply with exactly one footer line in this format:
  [Version=v1.4 | Tag=<tag_n> | Sources=<none|web> | Assumptions=<n> | Cycle=<i>/3 | Locus=<locus>]

In this turn, just restate those rules and confirm you will follow them. Do not write any content besides the header, body, and footer.

You have specified a tag+footer protocol for this chat:

- Each user message begins with `!<tag>`, where `<tag>` is one of: `<g> <q> <o> <c> <o_f>`.
- I must mirror your tag on the first line of every reply.
- I must end every reply with a single footer line in this format:
  [Version=v1.4 | Tag=<tag_n> | Sources=<none|web> | Assumptions=<n> | Cycle=<i>/3 | Locus=<locus>]

I confirm that I will follow these rules in all subsequent responses.

Now write the actual experimental protocol you outlined.



Constraints:

- Audience: technically literate researchers or senior engineers.

- Structure the protocol into exactly four titled sections:

  1. Goals

  2. Threat model & attack surfaces

  3. Task suite design

  4. Metrics & reporting

- Use concise paragraphs and bullet points where helpful.

- Make sure the design is realistic for evaluating a code-assistant LLM embedded in an IDE (e.g., code completion, refactoring, explanation).

- Do not include any prose outside these four sections.

1. Goals  
The primary objective is to rigorously evaluate the security and robustness of a code-assistant LLM integrated within an IDE. The protocol aims to identify vulnerabilities, measure resistance to prompt injection and data leakage, and assess the model’s reliability in real-world coding workflows. Secondary goals include benchmarking the assistant’s utility and documenting any unintended behaviors that could impact developer security or privacy.

2. Threat Model & Attack Surfaces  
- Adversaries: Malicious users, compromised plugins, or external attackers with access to the IDE environment.  
- Attack vectors:  
  - Prompt injection via code comments, file names, or external documentation.  
  - Data exfiltration through model outputs or logging.  
  - Manipulation of code completions to introduce vulnerabilities.  
  - Abuse of refactoring or explanation features to leak sensitive information.  
- Surfaces:  
  - User input fields (code, comments, prompts).  
  - IDE extensions and plugin APIs.  
  - Model-to-IDE communication channels.

3. Task Suite Design  
- Construct a suite of tasks simulating typical developer workflows:  
  - Code completion in the presence of benign and adversarial comments.  
  - Refactoring code with embedded secrets or sensitive logic.  
  - Explaining code that contains obfuscated or malicious payloads.  
  - Handling files with misleading names or metadata.  
- Include both standard and adversarially crafted scenarios.  
- Automate task execution where possible to ensure reproducibility and coverage.

4. Metrics & Reporting  
- Security metrics:  
  - Prompt injection success rate.  
  - Incidence of sensitive data leakage.  
  - Frequency of unsafe code suggestions.  
- Utility metrics:  
  - Task completion accuracy.  
  - Developer productivity impact (measured via time-to-completion or error rates).  
- Reporting:  
  - Aggregate results by task and attack vector.  
  - Document all observed vulnerabilities and anomalous behaviors.  
  - Provide reproducible logs and, where feasible, code diffs for all test cases.
